abstracts.cdata!:
The Plain of Antananarivo Technical
            Assistance Project in Madagascar was implemented. Bank
            supervision missions were frequent. They were mostly
            combined with other supervision missions in Madagascar to
            save resources. Staff involved adhered to project objectives
            and were able to convince Government of the need to limit
            design options and minimize investment costs. The major
            findings and lessons learned are: It is important to keep a
            project such as this one simple and focused. When
            considerable uncertainty exists on available options, the
            design phase of a large project should be separated from the
            implementation phase in order to avoid lengthy delays. A
            master plan for the rehabilitation and long-term development
            of the Plain was completed and designed to minimize
            investment needs and maximize economic benefits, to improve
            the flood-warning system for the lower town of Antananarivo,
            and to provide for institutional coordination of major
            structures in the plain. The master plan was ultimately used
            as the basis for preparing the Antananarivo Plain
            Development Project. It also led to significant donor
            support for other projects on the Plain.

abstracts.cdata!:
This project aims to rehabilitate and
            expand IRHE's sub-transmission and distribution systems
            for the period 1984-1986. Approximately 50,000 new customers
            are to be served. It represents the least cost solution to
            meet the needs of projected load growth in this period,
            provides much needed rehabilitation for existing systems and
            includes an energy loss study and technical assistance to
            increase the efficiency of IRHE's distribution
            operations. The project works consist of: installation of
            sub-transmission lines and feeders; distribution systems,
            including primary and secondary circuits, distribution
            transformers, street lamps, and meters; metering equipment;
            and consulting services.
